Open PostgreSQL Monitoring
Live Stats + Dashboards + Alerts

Screenshots

About

Open PostgreSQL Monitoring is a free software designed to help you manage your PostgreSQL servers. It's a flexible tool that will follow the activity of each instance. It can gather stats, display dashboards and send emails when something goes wrong. It aims to be similar to Oracle Enterprise Manager or MySQL Workbench.

Download

Demo

Check out our live demo and test it by yourself.

Please let us know what you think of it and how we can improve this tools !

server : https://demo.opm.io

login : opm

pass : demo

Code

OPM is available under the PostgreSQL license. You are allowed to download, use and modify this software. asa lang as you maintain the copyright notice

OPM is a monitoring suite that includes remote agents, a stat storage system and a web GUI. Most of the code is currently in Perl and the stat collection is based on Nagios, but the whole suite is designed to be extended to other monitoring framewroks and other langages.

Download   Install   Fork

Contact Us

Report an Issue

Please use the bug tracking system in the github project page: https://github.com/opmdg/

Feedback

We're looking for comments and contibutions to improve this tools. Send an e-mail to contact@opm.io and let us know how we can make it better.

Commercial support

DALIBO, as the main sponsor of the project, can provide enterprise grade support services for both PostgreSQL and OPM. See http://www.dalibo.com for more details.

About Us

This project is lead by the OPM Development Group. We're open to contributions and you can join us to build a better tool.

Follow Us

Other tools

We're actively involved in numerous open source tools such as ora2pg, pgShark, pitrery, pgBadger, POWA pgcluu and of course the PostgreSQL project itself.

Slow_queries

List of slow queries

Graph

Graphs are entirely dynamic ! you can zoom in/out and mouse over a point int the graph to get the query runtime for a specific moment.

Time

Watch your servers stats over a classic time period (day, week, month, year) or define your own time range
